item.title: Mauerfall
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: So, I could give you a great history of the Fall of the Berlin Wall (Mauerfall) and all that great and wonderful stuff, but I'm just going to refer you to the best source of all information in the universe: Wikipedia. Now that you're thoroughly informed, I feel that I can tell you about how Gorbachev was made fun of: the announcer ask Gorbi to explain what he did in terms of the Wall coming down, and Gorbi went on for...geez, 5-10 minutes, then the announcer concluded with "thank you for rushing yourself."  And the night before, at the rehearsals, the announcer said "and now, we're going to listen to Gorbachev ramble on about incohrerent nonsense, and then we'll cut to you!" But anyway...there's not much to say about the night, so I'm just going to attach a gallery so that you can see for yourself what I saw: I was standing relatively close to a jumbotron, and I could see nothing that was really going on besides that... Oh! Though it is worth noting that Gordon Brown is one of the biggest, most arrogant leaders in the world: "Britain is and always will be the heart of Europe."  He got booed.  Understandably. And, of course, the video clip from Obama silenced the crowd and got the biggest applause and cheering out of any of the foreign leaders present.[gallery]

item.title: Class Today
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
So, in class today, we had this awesome exchange:
Deubner: "Shevani, are you sure you're all right, you seem still sick." (Yes, still sick...I know). Shevani: "Yeah, I'm fine." D: "You sure?" S: "Maybe it's just your lecture."
And Deubner went on as though he didn't hear it...

item.title: Scotland! (Day 3)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
So, our last day in Scotland rolled around, and today was our tour of the Highlands!  The day, although consisting of seeing some very impressive and beautiful sights, was mainly composed of sitting on a bus and having stuff told to us as we drove by it.  Good times. Anyway, the tour started off pretty slow...and I mean slow.  Here, take a look:I do have to say, however, that I am now starting to understand that the differences between English and Germany are not merely because they are different languages: a lot of the strange things in German I saw repeated in the local Scottish Dialect of English.  It was rather fascinating, if I do say so myself. The above sign, for example, was far more common than "Exit."  Indeed, "Way Out" is apparently how you indicate an exit in a building.  And offices are "To Let," not "for lease."  And you get food "for take away," not "to go."  Same(ish) in German. But let's get to the tour...  The first mountain range we went through, we stopped at some mountains that...had something to do with history.  I just wanted to climb them.Then we went on to this little place...I don't remember where...but it was a big lake (I think it was before we got to Loch Ness).And then we ran into another cool scene...And somewhere in there, we stopped at a WWII memorial...But after all that, we finally got to Loch Ness!  At the start of our journey there, we stopped at a little castle (a destroyed one, too): Urquhart Castle.Isn't it gorgeous?  In my opinion, Nessy destroyed it because we wouldn't stop looking for her.  Oh well. Oh!  And did I mention how we found Nessy?!  Yeah, turns out she's saying "hi" to all the tourists these days...Adorable, isn't she?  A bit smaller than I expected, though. And then, we went further, and we finally got to Inverness (yeah, try saying that one: We were in Inverness).To say the least, this tour was rushed, and I don't really feel that it was a good use of our time, but hey, at least now I can say that I've literally been around the entire country of Scotland.  In one day.  Ouch. And finally, on this tour, they played this song a lot. It is such an awesome song that I just had to share:
Scotland the Brave.

item.title: And another class...
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Man...Deubner never ceases to amaze me with his masterful usage of the English language.
What will we be start with?
Well, I'm not sure, Deubner, but I think we will be start with...ouch! And then, it gets so much better...we were talking about the Iron Curtain, and Deubner said, and I quote:
And the Iron Curtain stopped criminals from coming from the poor east to the rich west and running their businesses here.  It was great.
He claims he was being sarcastic...but I'm not quite so sure.  Like I said, his English needs work, and he can't quite get sarcasm in English down...

item.title: Thanksgiving

Yeah, so we had our Thanksgiving dinner the night before Thanksgiving (that's today, right?).  But aside from the food, I just wanted to tell you something that happened before we met for dinner.  The best way to tell this is to give you a quote from the email we received:
Today, we were confronted with a not-too-pleasant surprise: the restaurant at which the Thanksgiving dinner was supposed to take place had to cancel the arrangement because ... their kitchen had burnt out over the weekend (there's something going on with fire this semester ...).
And that pretty much describes it :-D
